head.title: Anisotropic Surface Modulation of Pt Catalysts for Highly Reversible Li–O2 Batteries: High Index Facet as a Critical Descriptor | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Anisotropic Surface Modulation of Pt Catalysts for Highly Reversible Li–O2 Batteries: High Index Facet as a Critical Descriptor

The surface structure of solid catalysts has been regarded as a critical descriptor for determining the catalytic activities in various applications. However, structure-dependent catalytic activities have been rarely understood for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) within Li–O2 batteries. Here, we succeeded in the preparation of a Pt catalyst with an anisotropic structure and demonstrated its high catalytic activity in nonaqueous Li–O2 batteries. The cathode incorporating Pt exposed with high-index {411} facets showed greatly enhanced ORR and OER performance in comparison to commercial Pt/C cathode. The anisotropic Pt catalyst improved ORR activity with a large capacity of 12 985 mAh gcarbon–1, high rate performance, and stable cyclic retention up to 70 cycles with the capacity limited to 1000 mAh gcarbon–1. Furthermore, the anisotropic Pt catalyst exhibited high round-trip efficiency of ∼87% with a low OER potential (3.1 V) at a current density of 200 mA gcarbon–1. Our first-principles calculations revealed that the high-index facets, which contain step edge, kink, and ledge sites, are significantly more reactive than the low-index facets in terms of surface energy and O-binding energy.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
The surface structure of solid catalysts has been regarded as a critical descriptor for determining the catalytic activities in various applications. However, structure-dependent catalytic activities have been rarely understood for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) within Li–O
2
batteries. Here, we succeeded in the preparation of a Pt catalyst with an anisotropic structure and demonstrated its high catalytic activity in nonaqueous Li–O
2
batteries. The cathode incorporating Pt exposed with high-index {411} facets showed greatly enhanced ORR and OER performance in comparison to commercial Pt/C cathode. The anisotropic Pt catalyst improved ORR activity with a large capacity of 12 985 mAh g
carbon
–1
, high rate performance, and stable cyclic retention up to 70 cycles with the capacity limited to 1000 mAh g
carbon
–1
. Furthermore, the anisotropic Pt catalyst exhibited high round-trip efficiency of ∼87% with a low OER potential (3.1 V) at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
. Our first-principles calculations revealed that the high-index facets, which contain step edge, kink, and ledge sites, are significantly more reactive than the low-index facets in terms of surface energy and O-binding energy.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Li–O
2
batteries have been regarded as a promising next-generation battery for electric vehicles and energy storage systems due to their huge energy density, which is derived from Li oxidation to form insoluble lithium peroxide as the discharge reaction (2Li
+
+ O
2
+ 2e
–
→ Li
2
O
2
,
E
° = 2.96 V vs Li/Li
+
).
(1−7)
During the charge process, Li
2
O
2
should be completely decomposed for reversible long-term cycling. However, several critical obstacles are encountered, including the instability of the reaction
(8−13)
and high overpotential owing to sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and/or oxygen evolution reaction (OER),
(14−18)
which limit the practical applications of Li–O
2
batteries. In particular, the OER overpotential is mainly attributed to insoluble deposition and dense stacking of the insulating discharge products, including Li
2
O
2
, which impede Li
+
ion diffusion and e
–
transport, resulting in drastic cyclic degradation.
(19−24)
Hence, well-designed catalysts have been regarded as one of the key solutions to overcome these drawbacks.

On the basis of the Sabatier principle, noble metals have received much academic interest as catalysts in Li–O
2
batteries because their intrinsic half-filled antibonding states can have proper adsorption interaction with the discharge products.
(25)
Accordingly, the electronic band structure of the platinum (Pt) family of metal catalysts determines its catalytic activities in a volcano-shape trend. Therefore, one of the promising strategies to improve catalytic activity is alloying with other metals or metal oxides to control the surface composition of catalysts. For Pt-based alloys, the Shao-Horn group demonstrated that PtAu nanoparticles have bifunctional catalytic activity for ORR/OER, which achieved a high round-trip efficiency of 76% with an average voltage gap of ∼0.85 V at a current density of 50 mA g
carbon
–1
.
(26)
Thereafter, our group investigated the relationship between the catalytic activity of PdCu nanoparticles and the change of the electronic structure via the Cu atoms.
(27)
The PdCu exhibits a high round-trip efficiency of 80% with an average voltage gap of ∼0.66 V at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
, which is attributed to higher electron density of Pd on the top layer (donated by the underlying Cu atoms), thereby decreasing the adsorption strength of LiO
2
on the PdCu surface via electrostatic repulsion as elucidated by first-principles calculations. Kim et al. also claimed that the catalytic activity of Pt
3
Co alloy is inversely correlated with the adsorption strength of LiO
2
on the alloy surface, consistent with the calculated overpotentials.
(28)
Thus, Pt
3
Co nanoparticles achieved a high round-trip efficiency of 83% (average potential difference of about 0.56 V) at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
.

Another potential strategy is to change the shape of the catalyst to mediate the surface atomic arrangement and coordination.
(18,24)
This approach is well-documented for metal oxide catalysts in a Li–O
2
battery.
(18,24,29,30)
For example, the spinel Co
3
O
4
with different surface atomic arrangements via morphological change show significantly improved catalytic activities.
(24,31,32)
Su et al. reported the catalytic activities of nanometer-sized single crystals of Co
3
O
4
toward the Li–O
2
battery, where they found the catalytic activity to be dependent on the surface termination in the order of {100} < {110} < {112} < {111} planes.
(31)
In other words, the plane with a larger density of low-coordinated atoms and dangling bonds from the octahedral Co
3+
atoms is regarded as the active site (in contrast to the other tetrahedral Co
2+
termination), the increased presence of which is associated with improved catalytic activities and higher energy efficiency. In addition, Song et al. reported that the solid discharge product grows on the Co
3+
-exposed {112} facet of a Co
3
O
4
plate in a unique angular, conical morphology; growth on this facet is preferential over that on the carbon or Co
2+
-exposed {001} facet of Co
3
O
4
cubes.
(24)
However, compared to prior studies of a Pt-based catalyst in a Li–O
2
battery, a morphologically tailored catalyst with proper surface atomic arrangement on the Pt-based catalysts is unprecedented.
(33−38)
In this regard, the purpose of this work is to address the advantage of using an optimized atomic arrangement resulting from morphological characteristics to create a new breakthrough. Herein, we introduce the facile synthesis of anisotropic Pt catalysts, where the catalytic surfaces were exposed with high-index {411} facets along with several low-index facets to maximize the catalytic properties for the ORR/OER in the cathode of Li–O
2
batteries. Interestingly, the overpotentials of the anisotropic Pt catalysts toward ORR and OER were significantly reduced, and their round-trip efficiency reached 87% (average potential difference of approximately 0.40 V) at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
. The anisotropic Pt catalysts also showed a highly enhanced discharge rate capability. This greatly enhanced electrochemical performance for Li–O
2
batteries indicates that the anisotropic Pt catalysts could facilitate both ORR and OER processes. To our knowledge, this study on the high-index-faceted Pt nanostructure as a catalyst in Li–O
2
batteries is unprecedented to date.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: All materials were used without any further purification. The commercial Pt/C (40 wt % Pt) was purchased from Johnson Matthey Co. and used without further purification.

div.h3: Preparation of the Anisotropic {411}-Faceted Pt Catalysts
div.div:
The anisotropic Pt catalysts were prepared following a slightly modified procedure from a previous work.
(39)

The anisotropic {411}-faceted Pt catalysts were characterized using an X-ray diffraction (XRD) diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (Bruker New D8 Advance) at 40 kV/40 mA and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEOL JSM-6700F) operating voltages of 10 and 30 kV. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F30 operating at 300 kV, and the images were fast Fourier transformed (FFT) using the software Gatan DigitalMicrograph (version 3.11.0).

The electrodes and Li–O
2
cells were prepared as in previous procedures.
(18,27,39)
The cells were galvanostatically discharged and charged according to the discharge capacity and in the voltage window between 2.0 and 4.5 V. To stabilize the cycling, the cell was tested using a constant current–constant voltage (CC–CV) mode with potentiostatic steps at 4.2 V under the capacity limited to 1000 mAh g
carbon
–1
. The rate capability discharge tests were conducted to 2.0 V at current densities from 200 to 2000 mA g
carbon
–1
and charged with the capacity limited to 10000 mAh g
Li2O2
–1
. For the rate capability of the charge test, a commercial Li
2
O
2
was used as the cathode material. In detail, the electrode prefilled with Li
2
O
2
consisted of commercial Li
2
O
2
, catalyst, KB carbon, and a binder with a weight ratio of 80:9:8:3 on GDL. The average weight of Li
2
O
2
on the electrode was 8.9 mg. We also calculated the capacity based on the weight of Li
2
O
2
prepared for the charge electrode, which corresponded to ∼10000 mAh g
Li2O2
–1
.

The liquid electrolyte extracted from anisotropic Pt catalysts and KB electrodes after cycling were characterized using
1
H NMR (Bruker AMX-500 FT NMR). The liquid electrolytes after either first galvanostatic discharging to 2.0 V or charging to 4.0 V were extracted by 750 μL of D
2
O and transferred into an NMR tube. Chemical shifts were reported as ppm compared to 3-(trimethylsilyl)propionic-2,2,3,3-
d
4
acid, sodium salt (TMS, at 0 ppm) as an internal standard. The uncertainty of the NMR integration was 1.23% and was calculated as the percentage deviation from the expected value of the electrolyte solvent, i.e., the difference between the amount of methylene protons determined by integration and the theoretical amount [(16.2 – 16.0)/16.2 = 1.23%].

Identification and quantification of the gases evolved during charging of the Li–O
2
cell were performed using an in situ mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical HPR-20), as previously reported.
(39)
The discharged cell was purged with Ar for 1 h and then electrochemically charged, during which the gases evolved were analyzed by the mass spectrometer. A high galvanostatic current density of 1000 mA g
carbon
–1
was used so that the gas quantification could be reliably conducted.

The calculation details, including the program package
(40,41)
and method
(42)
used, are reported elsewhere.
(43)
We calculated the surface energies of the {111}, {100}, {110}, and {411} facets. Slab models with six Pt atomic layers were adopted, and each slab was separated by a 13 Å vacuum layer, creating two metal surfaces, and all of the atoms were allowed to relax. The surface energy is the work required to form the surface of a unit area, which is calculated as follows
where
S
is the surface area,
E
slab
is the total energy of the slab,
E
bulk
is the total energy of a bulk atom, and
N
is the number of atoms in the slab. To calculate the O-binding energies, slab models containing four layers of Pt atoms were used for simulation of the Pt surfaces and a 13 Å thick vacuum layer was added on the slab for elimination of interaction. The lattice constant of the Pt bulk was calculated to be 3.97 Å, in good agreement with the experimental data of 3.92 Å.
(44)
The closely packed low-index {111}, {100}, and {110} surfaces were modeled using 4 × 4 unit cells, and the anisotropic high-index {411} surface was modeled using a 4 × 1 unit cell. To optimize the O-adsorption structures, the bottom two layers were constrained to their bulk positions and the top two layers were completely relaxed.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Anisotropic {411}-faceted Pt catalysts were chemically synthesized by a polyol-mediated process at 200 °C for 2 h. The crystal structure and morphology of the anisotropic Pt catalysts were characterized using TEM and XRD.
Figure
1
a shows a low-magnification TEM image of the anisotropic Pt catalysts, with an average size of 50 nm. The as-synthesized Pt catalysts consisted of anisotropic branches with a diameter of 6.2 ± 0.4 nm.
Figure S1
shows the well-dispersed and uniform morphology of the anisotropic Pt catalysts. The crystal structure of anisotropic Pt catalysts was revealed in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and the corresponding FFT pattern. The HRTEM image shows a blow-up of the branch site at a single anisotropic Pt catalyst. As shown in
Figure
1
b, the TEM observation distinctly indicates that the anisotropic Pt catalysts were enclosed by high-index {411} facets along with several low-index facets, such as {100}, {110}, and {111}. The enlarged HRTEM image obtained from the partial region in the individual branch and the corresponding FFT pattern unequivocally prove that the exposed planes are high-index {411} based on the interplanar distances and angles of the {411} structure model, as shown in
Figure
1
c. Atomic steps, such as terraces, step edges, kinks, and ledges, which were exposed on the high-index {411} facet, were derived from the random growth of the branches on the anisotropic Pt catalysts (
Figure
1
d).
Figure
1
e displays the XRD pattern of the anisotropic Pt catalysts. Three peaks for the face-centered cubic (fcc) structure at 2θ = 39.9, 46.4, and 67.5° are well matched to the diffractions from the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Pt (JCPDS # 04-0802), respectively.

div.p: Figure 1. (a) TEM and (b) HRTEM images of the anisotropic Pt catalysts. The inset of (b) is the atomic model of the {411} facets exposed on the surface of the anisotropic Pt catalysts. (c) Enlarged HRTEM image and corresponding FFT pattern. (d) Schematic diagram of the atomic steps on the high-index facet. (e) XRD pattern of the anisotropic Pt catalysts.

div.div:
To investigate the catalytic activity of the anisotropic {411}-faceted Pt as a cathode catalyst in the Li–O
2
batteries, we constructed Swagelok-type cells with 1 M LiCF
3
SO
3
/TEGDME as an electrolyte, KB carbon as a conducting agent, Li metal foil as an anode, and glass fiber as a separator. The cells with O
2
to 1.1 atm were galvanostatically cycled at room temperature.

Figure
2
exhibits the initial galvanostatic discharge and charge profiles of Li–O
2
cells with the anisotropic Pt, commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon for the cathode catalysts at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
. We found that the discharge capacity of the anisotropic Pt was significantly greater than the discharge capacity of the commercial Pt/C and the KB carbon. Actually, the initial discharge capacity of the anisotropic Pt (12985 mAh g
carbon
–1
) was more than 2–3 times greater than those of the commercial Pt/C (6272 mAh g
carbon
–1
) and the KB carbon (3622 mAh g
carbon
–1
). The anisotropic Pt showed a higher discharge potential than the commercial Pt/C with characteristic plateaus at 2.7 V. It is noteworthy that the discharge potential of the anisotropic Pt catalysts is similar to the theoretical potential of Li
2
O
2
formation. The charge reaction was also greatly improved by using the anisotropic Pt catalysts, in comparison to previously reported catalysts.
(45−50)
The charge profile for the catalyst-free electrode that only had KB carbon exhibited a very high overpotential, leading to a charge potential of 4.2 V; this demonstrates that this electrode did not show any catalytic reaction for OER. The charge profile for the commercial Pt/C has a slightly lower overpotential, with a charge potential of 4.0 V. However, the anisotropic Pt catalyst showed an overpotential that was 0.8 V lower than the commercial Pt/C catalyst, which is unprecedented. From the above results, it can be strongly demonstrated that the anisotropic Pt catalysts have superior catalytic activities for ORR and OER in Li–O
2
batteries (
Figures S2 and S3
).

div.p:
Figure 2. Galvanostatic discharge and charge profiles of the Li–O
2
cells using anisotropic Pt, commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon as the cathode catalysts.

div.div:
Figure S4
comparatively illustrates the cyclic retention of the anisotropic Pt, commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon electrodes. The capacity of the anisotropic Pt electrode was maintained at over 2000 mAh g
carbon
–1
even after five cycles, whereas the capacities of the commercial Pt/C and the KB carbon electrodes were decreased to 59 and 200 mAh g
carbon
–1
, respectively.
Figure S5
shows the XRD patterns of the pristine, discharged, and charged electrodes. In contrast to the XRD patterns of the pristine and the charged electrodes, Li
2
O
2
diffraction peaks were detected on the discharged electrode. This result demonstrates that Li
2
O
2
was formed during discharging of the anisotropic Pt electrode, while Li
2
O
2
completely disappeared after the charging process. Thus, the anisotropic Pt catalysts enabled superior reversibility during ORR/OER in Li–O
2
batteries.

SEM images of the pristine, discharged, and charged electrodes using the anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C catalysts confirm the discharged product and cell reversibility during the repetitive discharge/charge processes (
Figure
3
). Regardless of the type of catalyst that was incorporated, the pristine electrodes show a large number of pores, which enables easy diffusion of Li
+
ions and O
2
gas into the cathode interface (
Figure
3
a,d). The large toroid-shape of the discharged product (Li
2
O
2
) is typical for the Li–O
2
cells,
(51)
but a toroid-shaped Li
2
O
2
larger than the critical size (≥1 μm) can lead to a higher OER overpotential, followed by poor electrochemical performance.
Figure S6
verifies the typical toroidal shape of Li
2
O
2
grown on the KB carbon catalyst. A unique two-dimensional (2D) sheet shape of Li
2
O
2
was formed on the discharged electrode of the anisotropic Pt catalysts (
Figure
3
b). In addition, the SEM image of the discharged commercial Pt/C electrode revealed that the spherical-, spindle-, and irregular-shaped Li
2
O
2
particles are small (
Figure
3
e). Therefore, it was confirmed that the electrode composed of Pt-based catalysts, such as anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C, normally forms significantly reduced particle sizes of Li
2
O
2
in comparison to the catalyst-free electrode when only KB carbon is used as the conducting agent.

div.p: Figure 3. SEM images of (a) the pristine anisotropic Pt electrode and the anisotropic Pt electrodes after (b) discharge and (c) charge. SEM images of (d) the pristine commercial Pt/C electrode and the commercial Pt/C electrodes after (b) discharge and (f) charge.

div.div:
It has been reported that a smaller particle size (≤150 nm) of Li
2
O
2
leads to a lower charge overpotential and improved round-trip efficiency.
(52)
Furthermore, we previously proved that the 2D sheet shape of Li
2
O
2
is easily decomposed during the charge reaction with a reduced overpotential and increased reaction kinetics.
(27)
Moreover, (0001) surfaces with a relatively lower energy barrier for the decomposition may be exposed on the 2D sheet shape of Li
2
O
2
.
(53)
In this regard, Li
2
O
2
on the surface of the anisotropic Pt electrode completely disappeared after the charge reaction (
Figure
3
c), indicating that Li
2
O
2
can be reversibly decomposed during OER thanks to the catalytic activity of the anisotropic Pt. We believe that the high-index {411} facets with a higher density of low-coordinate atomic steps were responsible for this superb catalytic activity for ORR and OER. In addition, we suggest that anisotropic Pt catalysts facilitate the concrete growth seed for the unique 2D growth of Li
2
O
2
during the discharge reaction. Because the anisotropic Pt catalysts offer sufficient density for the facet with high surface energy consisting of the atomic steps, such as step edges, kinks, and ledges for Li
2
O
2
nucleation, it seems that Li
2
O
2
can grow with a 2D sheet shape without any toroid growth. Meanwhile, the KB carbon and commercial Pt/C catalysts have insufficient active sites that lead to toroid-, spherical-, spindle-, and irregular-shaped Li
2
O
2
particles.

To elucidate the dependency of catalytic activity on the high-index facets, we calculated the surface energies of the high-index {411} facet of the Pt surface as well as the low-index facets, such as {111}, {100}, and {110}, using first-principles calculations. The optimized structures of the considered Pt surfaces are shown in
Figure
4
, and the calculated surface energies are listed in
Table S1
. The surface structure of the high-index {411} facet is rough with atomic steps, while the low-index {111}, {100}, and {110} facets are flat with closely packed surface atoms. The surface energy of 0.29 eV/Å
2
of the high-index {411} facet was much larger than those of the low-index facets (0.09–0.12 eV/Å
2
). The atomic steps on high-index facets possibly form step structures, such as step edges, kinks, and ledges, as depicted in the schematic image (
Figure
1
d). The coordination numbers of the step atoms (step edge: 7; kink: 6; and ledge: 5) are lower than those of the surface atoms on the low-index facets ({111} facet: 9; {100} facet: 8; and {110} facet: 7). The increased density of the low-coordinate atoms and the high surface energy of the high-index facets are considered to be the possible reasons for the enhanced catalytic activity of anisotropic Pt catalysts.

div.p: Figure 4. Optimized structures of (a) {111}, (b) {100}, (c) {110}, and (d) {411} Pt surfaces and O-adsorbed structures on the (e) {111}, (f) {100}, (g) {110}, and (h) {411} Pt surfaces. Color code: blue = top-layer Pt; gray = subsurface Pt; and red = O atoms.

div.div:
The O-binding energy is typically used as a descriptor to predict the activity of a catalyst, and we calculated it for the various facets of the Pt surface. The O-adsorbed structures on the low-index facets {111}, {100}, and {110} and the high-index {411} facet are shown in
Figure
4
e-h, and the calculated O-binding energies are given in
Table S1
. The high-index {411} facet has a much larger O-binding energy of 1.48 eV than the low-index facets (0.76–1.26 eV), and this finding is in good harmony with the largest surface energy of the high-index {411} facet. Furthermore, we also calculated the O-binding energies on the step edge, kink, and ledge sites, which are possibly formed at the atomic steps of high-index facets; the O-adsorption structures are given in
Figure
5
. Step edge (1.48 eV), kink (1.48 eV), and ledge (1.52 eV) sites were found to exhibit strong binding with an O atom. The existence of atomic step sites with strong O-binding energies on high-index facets can further facilitate a catalytic reaction. Consequently, the anisotropic Pt catalyst with exposed high-index and high-energy facets undergoes unique 2D growth of Li
2
O
2
on its surface and finally shows significantly improved catalytic activity.

div.p: Figure 5. Optimized O-adsorbed structures on the (a) step edge, (b) kink, and (c) ledge sites of Pt surfaces. Color code: gray = Pt; red = O; and green = terrace-layer Pt atoms.

div.div:
Figure
6
shows the energy profiles of ORR and OER on the Pt(411) surface, which illustrate the Li
x
O
2
(
x
= 1, 2, and 4) adsorption/desorption steps along the ORR and OER pathways. Here, three elementary reaction steps were considered: (1) Li + O
2
→ LiO
2
, (2) LiO
2
+ Li → Li
2
O
2
, and (3) Li
2
O
2
+ 2Li → (Li
2
O)
2
.
(27,28,54,55)
For the Pt(411) surface, we obtained ORR and OER overpotentials of 0.99 and 1.20 V, respectively, as shown in
Figure
6
. Han et al. reported that the calculated ORR and OER overpotentials for Pt(111) are 1.02 and 1.62 V, respectively.
(55)
It is worth noting that the OER overpotential on the Pt(411) surface is 0.42 V lower than that of the Pt(111) surface. On the contrary, the ORR overpotential difference between the Pt(411) and Pt(111) surfaces is small (0.03 V). These calculation results are qualitatively consistent with our experimental results.

div.p:
Figure 6. ORR and OER energy diagrams calculated with Li
x
O
2
(
x
= 1, 2, and 4) adsorption structures on the Pt(411). Color code: gray = Pt; yellow = Li; red = O; and green = terrace site Pt.

div.div:
The rate capability is also an important parameter for high-power-density devices, such as electric vehicles and energy storage systems.
Figure
7
a,b compares the rate capabilities that were tested by varying the galvanostatic current densities from 200 to 2000 mA g
carbon
–1
for the discharge and charge processes, respectively. The Li–O
2
cell with the anisotropic Pt catalysts was found to have a three times greater discharge capacity (1500 mAh g
carbon
–1
) than the cell with the commercial Pt/C (500 mAh g
carbon
–1
) at the high current density of 2000 mA g
carbon
–1
. Because the charge potential profiles significantly depend on the shape and size of Li
2
O
2
,
(52,56)
we cannot exclude the effect of discharge products on OER in the case of a normal cell experiment. Thus, for an intrinsic comparison of the OER catalytic activities between the anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C catalysts, the charge reactions were conducted under the same condition using a commercial Li
2
O
2
. Electrodes were prepared by mechanically mixing the commercial Li
2
O
2
, catalyst (anisotropic Pt or Pt/C), KB carbon, and PVDF-HFP binder with the weight ratio of 80:9:8:3 (Li
2
O
2
:catalyst:KB: PVDF-HFP). The average Li
2
O
2
weight of the cathode was 2.16 mg (6.8 mW
cell
; average potential: 2.7 V vs Li/Li
+
). When we calculated the capacity based on the weight of Li
2
O
2
in the charged cathode, the calculated capacity (2.52 mAh from the weight of Li
2
O
2
) was identical to the experimental capacity (∼2.52 mAh at ∼4.4 V in 2000 mA g
–1
of current density), as shown in
Figure S7
.

div.p:
Figure 7. (a) Discharge and (b) charge potential profiles of the Li–O
2
cells using the anisotropic Pt and the commercial Pt/C at current densities from 200 to 2000 mA g
carbon
–1
. The charge electrode was constructed using a mixture of commercial Li
2
O
2
, the anisotropic Pt or commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon. (c) Initial discharge/charge curves when the capacity is limited to less than 1000 mA g
carbon
–1
and (d) cyclic retentions with capacity limited to 1000 mAh g
carbon
–1
.

div.div:
Figure
7
b presents the charge potential profiles of the Li–O
2
cells using anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C as catalysts. The anisotropic Pt catalysts exhibited about 500 mV lower charge potential than the commercial Pt/C catalyst at 200 mA g
carbon
–1
, once more demonstrating that the OER catalytic activity of the anisotropic Pt is much greater than that of the commercial Pt/C. The main reason for this difference seems to be due to the high-energy facet of the anisotropic Pt catalysts with atomic steps, such as step edges, kinks, and ledges, and morphological characteristics, which enable three-dimensional (3D) contact between the catalytic active surface of the anisotropic Pt catalysts and the discharge products. We also evaluated the charge reaction to determine the corresponding Li
2
O
2
decomposition depending on the type of catalyst. The charge potential profiles of the anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C catalysts were also obtained at high current densities of 1000 and 2000 mA g
carbon
–1
. When the charge current density increased, the operating potential clearly increased, probably due to the surge of internal resistance in the Li–O
2
cells. Even at these higher charge current densities, the charge overpotential of the anisotropic Pt catalysts was surprisingly about 100 mV lower than it was for the commercial Pt/C catalyst.

To evaluate the structural changes of the electrodes during this experiment, we conducted ex situ XRD analysis.
Figure S8
shows the XRD patterns of the pristine electrode prefilled with Li
2
O
2
and the charged electrodes using anisotropic Pt or commercial Pt/C as the cathode catalyst. The XRD pattern of the pristine electrode prefilled with Li
2
O
2
using the anisotropic Pt as the catalyst shows the high intensity of the Li
2
O
2
peaks, while the XRD pattern of the charged electrode with anisotropic Pt catalysts demonstrated that the commercial Li
2
O
2
was completely decomposed. However, the peaks related to Li
2
O
2
could still be seen and are even stronger than the reflections from the gas diffusion layer, which is attributed to residual Li
2
O
2
covering the Pt/C electrode surface. This implies that anisotropic Pt catalysts can facilitate the effective decomposition of Li
2
O
2
during the charging process, whereas the catalytic activity of the commercial Pt/C catalyst seems to be insufficient to completely decompose Li
2
O
2
.

In order to duly evaluate the cyclability of the Li–O
2
battery, the Li–O
2
cells were also tested using CC–CV mode with the capacity limited to 1000 mAh g
carbon
–1
.
Figure
7
c shows the typical discharge and charge profiles of the Li–O
2
cell with the anisotropic Pt, commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon catalysts at a current density of 200 mA g
carbon
–1
. The anisotropic Pt electrode had the lowest ORR/OER overpotentials in comparison to the commercial Pt/C and KB carbon electrodes. Thus, the first cycle round-trip efficiency of the anisotropic Pt catalysts reached 87%, which was even higher than the best results reported in the literature using metal oxides, carbonaceous materials, and noble metal-based catalysts (
Table S2
).
(13,18,26−28,46−49,57−60)

Figure
7
d presents the cyclic retentions of the anisotropic Pt, commercial Pt/C, and KB carbon catalysts. The discharge/charge curves of the anisotropic Pt and commercial Pt/C were measured after every 10 cycles of the retention test (
Figure S9
). The discharge capacity of the anisotropic Pt is stable over 70 cycles, while the discharge capacities for the commercial Pt/C and KB carbon are stable for 40 cycles and 17 cycles, respectively. This demonstrates that the Pt-based catalysts facilitate the reversible reactions of Li–O
2
batteries at least over 40 cycles, and they do not promote any unwanted irreversible reaction related to the additional electrolyte decomposition. The McCloskey group claimed that Pt catalysts thermochemically promote reduction of O
2
gas, yielding reactive oxygen species including O
2
–
radicals on the Pt surface at room temperature; consequently, an ether-based electrolyte can be decomposed and emit CO
2
even under 4.0 V if the solvent encounters the O species generated on the Pt surface.
(61)
That research study also pointed out that the reduced charging potential obtained when using a Pt/carbon catalyst is mainly due to the decomposition of LiRCO
3
; thus, the dominant CO
2
evolution occurs at the relatively low potential of about 3.6 V.
(61)
Although McCloskey et al. demonstrated that the Li–O
2
battery using a Pt catalyst can accelerate the side reaction in an ether-based electrolyte system, that side reaction was proven to primarily result from the intrinsic instability of the electrolyte, carbon, and binder against the nucleophilic attack by O
2–
ions. The formation of byproducts from parasitic reactions could be interpreted by the instability of the current Li–O
2
battery systems on the basis of ex situ XRD, FT-IR (
Figure S10
), Raman analysis (
Figure S11
),
1
H NMR spectra (
Figure S12 and S13
), and DEMS results (
Figure S14
) by comparing spectroscopic results between KB and anisotropic Pt electrodes. Both electrodes obviously show Li
2
O
2
peaks in FT-IR and Raman analysis after the discharging process, which reversibly disappeared after the charging process without impacting the typical electrolyte spectroscopic signals in both KB and anisotropic Pt electrodes. In addition, we performed
1
H NMR analysis for the electrolytes extracted from anisotropic Pt and KB electrodes to investigate electrolyte stability. The electrolyte solvent, TEGDME, has three proton environments: 6 protons from terminal methyl groups (CH
3
), 4 protons from the methylenes closest to the terminal methyls (H
3
C–O–CH
2
–CH
2
–O−), and 12 protons from the remaining methylenes (H
3
C–O–CH
2
–CH
2
–O−). In this regard, the spectra, shown in
Figures S12 and S13
, demonstrated that the HO–R–CH
3
and HCO
2
Li byproducts are generated on both anisotropic Pt and KB electrodes. The amounts of HO–R–CH
3
and HCO
2
Li were quantified by integrating the relevant NMR signals, and the results are tabulated in
Tables S3 and S4
. It can be seen here that the amounts of decomposition products are essentially identical in both KB and our anisotropic Pt within the experimental uncertainty of this technique. Furthermore, our DEMS data revealed that O
2
gas evolution is dominantly observed and the CO
2
gas evolution was initiated primarily above 4.2 V when adopting our anisotropic Pt catalyst (
Figure S14
). The quantification of the number of electrons/O
2
of KB and anisotropic Pt shows identical values that, together with the NMR results, demonstrate that our anisotropic Pt does not additionally accelerate the side reaction of the electrolyte compared to KB. In this regard, we believe that the high surface energy of anisotropic Pt catalysts can strongly attract the O
2–
ion, thereby reducing the side reaction on carbon or the binder. As shown in
Figure S15
, the shape of the anisotropic Pt catalysts was well preserved even after 70 cycles without any deformation and agglomeration, which strongly supports that the anisotropic Pt catalysts were surprisingly stable for ORR/OER in Li–O
2
batteries.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, anisotropic Pt catalysts were successfully synthesized using a polyol process and utilized as the cathode catalyst in a nonaqueous Li–O
2
battery. The anisotropic Pt catalysts were found to greatly enhance the catalytic activities for ORR and OER in comparison to those for a commercial Pt/C. In addition, the anisotropic Pt catalysts exhibited highly enhanced capacity (12985 mAh g
carbon
–1
), superior round-trip efficiency (87%), and stable cyclability for the Li–O
2
battery. The electrochemical experiments coupled with first-principles calculations confirmed that these enhancements can be attributed to the characteristic high-index {411} facet on the surface of anisotropic Pt catalysts.

This electrochemical superiority of anisotropic Pt catalysts verifies the correlation between the high-energy facet enabling the unique 2D sheet shape of Li
2
O
2
and the catalytic activity for Li–O
2
batteries. Therefore, designing a catalyst surface structure with favorable active sites and high surface energy for ORR/OER may accelerate the commercialization of Li–O
2
batteries in the near future. On the basis of our current understanding of anisotropic high-index-faceted Pt catalysts, we believe that the high-surface-energy facet will be valid for different metal and metal oxide catalysts for Li–O
2
batteries.

Reaction chemistry in rechargeable Li-O2 batteries
Lim, Hee-Dae; Lee, Byungju; Bae, Youngjoon; Park, Hyeokjun; Ko, Youngmin; Kim, Haegyeom; Kim, Jinsoo; Kang, Kisuk
Chemical Society Reviews

The seemingly simple reaction of Li-O2 batteries involving lithium and oxygen makes this chem. attractive for high-energy-d. storage systems; however, achieving this reaction in practical rechargeable Li-O2 batteries has proven difficult. The reaction paths leading to the final Li2O2 discharge products can be greatly affected by the operating conditions or environment, which often results in major side reactions. Recent research findings have begun to reveal how the reaction paths may be affected by the surrounding conditions and to uncover the factors contributing to the difficulty in achieving the reactions of lithium and oxygen. This progress report describes the current state of understanding of the electrode reaction mechanisms in Li-O2 batteries; the factors that affect reaction pathways; and the effect of cell components such as solvents, salts, additives, and catalysts on the discharge product and its decompn. during charging. This comprehensive review of the recent progress in understanding the reaction chem. of the Li-O2 system will serve as guidelines for future research and aid in the development of reliable high-energy-d. rechargeable Li-O2 batteries.

For the promotion of lithium-oxygen batteries available for practical applications, the development of advanced cathode catalysts with low-cost, high activity, and stable structural properties is demanded. Such development is rooted on certain intelligent catalyst-electrode design that fundamentally facilitates electronic and ionic transport and improves oxygen diffusivity in a porous environment. Here we design a biphasic nitrogen-doped
[email protected]
multiple-capsule heterostructure, combined with a flexible, stable porous electrode architecture, and apply it as promising cathodes for lithium-oxygen cells. The biphasic nitrogen-doping feature improves the elec. cond. and catalytic activity; the multiple-nanocapsule configuration makes high/uniform electroactive zones possible; furthermore, the colander-like porous electrode facilitates the oxygen diffusion, catalytic reaction, and stable deposition of discharge products. As a result, the electrode exhibits much improved electrocatalytic properties assocd. with unique morphologies of electrochem. grown lithium peroxides.

Ultrahigh-Capacity Lithium-Oxygen Batteries Enabled by Dry-Pressed Holey Graphene Air Cathodes
Lin, Yi; Moitoso, Brandon; Martinez-Martinez, Chalynette; Walsh, Evan D.; Lacey, Steven D.; Kim, Jae-Woo; Dai, Liming; Hu, Liangbing; Connell, John W.

Lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries have the highest theor. energy d. of all the Li-based energy storage systems, but many challenges prevent them from practical use. A major obstacle is the sluggish performance of the air cathode, where both oxygen redn. (discharge) and oxygen evolution (charge) reactions occur. Recently, there have been significant advances in the development of graphene-based air cathode materials with a large surface area and catalytically active for both oxygen redn. and evolution reactions, esp. with addnl. catalysts or dopants. However, most studies reported so far have examd. air cathodes with a limited areal mass loading rarely exceeding 1 mg/cm2. Despite the high gravimetric capacity values achieved, the actual (areal) capacities of those batteries were far from sufficient for practical applications. Here, we present the fabrication, performance, and mechanistic investigations of high-mass-loading (up to 10 mg/cm2) graphene-based air electrodes for high-performance Li-O2 batteries. Such air electrodes could be easily prepd. within minutes under solvent-free and binder-free conditions by compression-molding holey graphene materials because of their unique dry compressibility assocd. with in-plane holes on the graphene sheet. Li-O2 batteries with high air cathode mass loadings thus prepd. exhibited excellent gravimetric capacity as well as ultrahigh areal capacity (as high as ∼40 mAh/cm2). The batteries were also cycled at a high curtailing areal capacity (2 mAh/cm2) and showed a better cycling stability for ultrathick cathodes than their thinner counterparts. Detailed post-mortem analyses of the electrodes clearly revealed the battery failure mechanisms under both primary and secondary modes, arising from the oxygen diffusion blockage and the catalytic site deactivation, resp. These results strongly suggest that the dry-pressed holey graphene electrodes are a highly viable architectural platform for high-capacity, high-performance air cathodes in Li-O2 batteries of practical significance.

Hu, Xiaofei; Wang, Jianbin; Li, Zifan; Wang, Jiaqi; Gregory, Duncan H.; Chen, Jun

Li-air batteries (LABs) are promising because of their high energy d. However, LABs are troubled by large electrochem. polarization during discharge and charge, side reactions from both carbon cathode surface/peroxide product and electrolyte/superoxide intermediate, as well as the requirement for pure O2. Here we report the soln. using multiwall carbon nanotubes (MCNTs)@MnO2 nanocomposite cathode integrated with N,N'-bis(salicylidene)ethylenediaminocobalt(II) (CoII-salen) in electrolyte for LABs. The advantage of such a combination is that on one hand, the coating layer of δ-MnO2 with about 2-3 nm on
[email protected]
nanocomposite catalyzes Li2O2 decompn. during charge and suppresses side reactions between product Li2O2 and MCNT surface. On the other hand, CoII-salen works as a mobile O2-carrier and accelerates Li2O2 formation through the reaction of (CoIII-salen)2-O22- + 2Li+ + 2e- → 2CoII-salen + Li2O2. This reaction route overcomes the pure O2 limitation and avoids the formation of aggressive superoxide intermediate (O2- or LiO2), which easily attacks org. electrolyte. By using this double-catalyst system of Co-salen/
[email protected]
, the lifetime of LABs is prolonged to 300 cycles at 500 mA g-1 (0.15 mA cm-2) with fixed capacity of 1000 mAh g-1 (0.30 mAh cm-2) in dry air (21% O2). Furthermore, we up-scale the capacity to 500 mAh (5.2 mAh cm-2) in pouch-type batteries (∼4 g, 325 Wh kg-1). This study should pave a new way for the design and construction of practical LABs.

Despite the extraordinary gravimetric energy densities, lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries are still facing a technol. challenge; limited round trip efficiency leading to insufficient cycle life. Recently, carbonaceous electrode materials were found to be one of the primary origins of the limited cycle life, as they produce irreversible side products during discharge. A few investigations based on noncarbonaceous materials have demonstrated largely suppressed accumulation of irreversible side products, but such studies have focused mainly on the materials themselves rather than delicate morphol. control. As such, here, we report the synthesis of mesoporous titanium nitride (m-TiN) with a 2D hexagonal structure and large pores (>30 nm), which was templated by a block copolymer with tunable chain lengths, and introduce it as a stable air-cathode backbone. Due to the well-aligned pore structure and decent elec. cond. of TiN, the battery reaction was quite reversible, resulting in robust cycling performance for over 100 cycles under a potential cutoff condition. Furthermore, by protecting the Li metal with a poreless polyurethane separator and engaging a lithium iodide redox mediator, the original capacity was retained for 280 cycles under a consistent capacity condition (430 mAh g-1). This study reveals that when the appropriate structure and material choice of the air-cathode are coupled with an advanced separator and an effective soln.-phase redox mediator, the cycle lives of Li-O2 batteries can be enhanced dramatically.

A review. This paper reviews the technol. progress and challenges regarding Li-O2 batteries. The largest of these scientific challenges are a result of Li2O2 formation/oxidn. as the active obsd. cathode reaction; in particular, electrolyte and cathode instabilities in the presence of reduced oxygen species and charge transport limitations through insol. Li3O2 deposits on the cathode surface. These issues not only deleteriously affect long-term rechargeability, but also result in the large obsd. charge overpotentials and limited capacity. Redox mediators are an interesting concept to improve charge transport during discharge and charge, and studies to further understand and optimize redox mediation in Li-O2 batteries are encouraged. Nevertheless, redox mediators are susceptible to degrdn. during battery operation and in some cases can induce degrdn. of other cell components. They also can act as an electron shuttle between the cathode and anode rather than as a Li2O2 oxidn. mediator. Therefore, any studies on the viability of new redox mediators should provide quant. measurements of product formation and reactant consumption to confirm their performance. Of importance for the viability of heterogeneous electrocatalysis, the primary causes for the obsd. overpotentials on discharge and charge in a Li-O3 battery are not related to the kinetics of the ORR and OER reactions, but instead result from transport limitations and electrolyte degrdn. that deposits products that block the O2 evolving interface. Therefore, instead of research toward improving active ORR/OER heterogeneous electrocatalysts, the authors encourage research into strategies that improve the stability of cathode materials and eliminate their electrocatalytic behavior toward electrolyte degrdn.

Cathode design is indispensable for building Li-O2 batteries with long cycle life. A composite of carbon-wrapped Mo2C nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes is prepd. on Ni foam by direct hydrolysis and carbonization of a gel composed of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate and hydroquinone resin. The Mo2C nanoparticles with well-controlled particle size act as a highly active oxygen redn. reactions/oxygen evolution reactions (ORR/OER) catalyst. The carbon coating can prevent the aggregation of the Mo2C nanoparticles. The even distribution of Mo2C nanoparticles results in the homogenous formation of discharge products. The skeleton of porous carbon with carbon nanotubes protrudes from the composite, resulting in extra voids when applied as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries. The batteries deliver a high discharge capacity of ≈10 400 mAh g-1 and a low av. charge voltage of ≈4.0 V at 200 mA g-1. With a cutoff capacity of 1000 mAh g-1, the Li-O2 batteries exhibit excellent charge-discharge cycling stability for over 300 cycles. The av. potential polarization of discharge/charge gaps is only ≈0.9 V, demonstrating the high ORR and OER activities of these Mo2C nanoparticles. The excellent cycling stability and low potential polarization provide new insights into the design of highly reversible and efficient cathode materials for Li-O2 batteries.

A review. Many studies recognize that membrane lithium air batteries (LABs) are preferable to non-membrane lithium air batteries for future applications as an energy source. An intensive collection of work was published several years ago regarding air cathodes, lithium metal anodes, and electrolytes, among others. Typically, the membrane is sandwiched between an air cathode and a lithium metal anode and protects the anode from any impurities such as oxygen and water that diffuse from cathode to anode in LABs. Membranes have been used as electrolytes and separators and have been used at the outer side of the cathode and the inner side of the cathode and anode in LABs. Therefore, there is an urgent need to discuss the potential advantages of different membranes to understand the possible mitigations of challenges related to LABs. This review examines the effectiveness of various membranes in the primary components of LABs, including air cathodes, lithium metal anodes, electrolytes and electrodes. Several membranes were effective in limiting the gas permeation and water permeability in LABs. The prospects of these membranes in LABs are detd. by their efficacy in overcoming the related problems that work against the energy storage in LABs for future studies.

Lithium iodide has been studied extensively as a redox-mediator to reduce the charging overpotential of Li-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries. Ambiguities exist regarding the influence of lithium iodide on the reaction product chem. and performance of lithium-oxygen batteries. In this work, we examd. the role of lithium iodide on the redn. product chem. under two conditions: (i) mixing KO2 with lithium salts and (ii) discharging Li-oxygen batteries at high and low overpotentials, in the presence of an ether-based electrolyte with different ratios of H2O : LiI. The addn. of iodide to electrolytes contg. water was found to promote the formation of LiOOH·H2O, LiOH·H2O and LiOH at the expense of Li2O2. At low H2O : LiI ratios (lower than 5), LiOH instead of Li2O2 was formed, which was accompanied by the oxidn. of iodide to triiodide while at high H2O : LiI ratios (12, 24, 134), a mixt. of Li2O2, LiOOH·H2O and LiOH·H2O was obsd. and no triiodide was detected. The reaction between peroxide Li2O2 and/or superoxide LiO2 with H2O to form LiOH is facilitated by increased water acidity by strong I--H2O interactions as revealed by 1H NMR and FT-IR measurements. This mechanism of LiOH formation in the presence of LiI and H2O was also found upon Li-O2 cell discharge, which is crit. to consider when developing LiI as a redox mediator for Li-O2 batteries.

Li-air batteries have attracted intensive recent research attention owing to their extremely high energy d. that is ten times that of the conventional Li-ion batteries; however, achieving this energy capability in practical Li-air batteries has been proven to be difficult. A lot of effort has been devoted to improving their stability, energy efficiency and cycle life with a better understanding of the reaction mechanisms. The electrochem. processes assocd. with the reversible formation/decompn. of Li2O2 are affected by the surrounding conditions, which often involve several side reactions. In this review, we summarize recent progress in Li-air batteries, esp. in the side reactions taking place in the electrochem. process, including carbon corrosion in the cathodes, electrolyte degrdn., and the shuttle effect of redox mediators in the electrolytes as well as contaminants from the air (CO2, H2O, and N2). The main strategies for suppressing or making full use of these side reactions for enhancing the performance of Li-air batteries are presented. Meanwhile, we also provide perspectives on the development of Li-air batteries.

However, the poor cycling stability and low energy efficiency of Li-O2 batteries still remain and hamper their practical application. Configuring desirable porous cathodes with uniformly dispersed and highly active catalysts is a noteworthy and feasible approach to overcoming these crit. obstacles. Herein, we report on a novel strategy for the fabrication of Mn3O4 nanowires and carbon nanotubes composite film (Mn3O4/CNTs film) with ultrafine RuO2 nanoparticles (Mn3O4/CNTs-RuO2 film), in which the Mn3O4/CNTs film was employed as a conductive and porous matrix and extremely low amt. of RuO2 (just 2.84 wt%) are uniformly dispersed onto this matrix by using at. layer deposition method, and reveal its electrochem. behaviors as a free-standing air electrode for Li-O2 batteries. The performances of a Li-O battery depend on a complex interplay between the reaction mechanism at the cathode, the chem. structure and the morphol. of the reaction products, and their spatial and temporal evolution; all parameters that, in turn, are dependent on the choice of the electrolyte. In an aprotic cell, for example, the discharge product, Li2O2, forms through a combination of soln. and surface chemistries that results in the formation of a baffling toroidal morphol. In a solid electrolyte, neither the reaction mechanism at the cathode nor the nature of the reaction product is known. We report the full-cycle reaction pathway for Li-O batteries and show how this correlates with the morphol. of the reaction products. Using aberration-cor. environmental transmission electron microscopy (TEM) under an O environment, we image the product morphol. evolution on a C nanotube (CNT) cathode of a working solid-state Li-O nanobattery and correlate these features with the electrochem. reaction at the electrode. We find that the O-redn. reaction (ORR) on CNTs initially produces LiO2, which subsequently disproportionates into Li2O2 and O. The release of O creates a hollow nanostructure with Li2O outer-shell and Li2O2 inner-shell surfaces. Our findings show that, in general, the way the released O is accommodated is linked to Li-ion diffusion and electron-transport paths across both spatial and temporal scales; in turn, this interplay governs the morphol. of the discharging/charging products in Li-O cells.

Li-O2 batteries provide high-capacity energy storage, but for aprotic Li-O2 batteries, it is reported that the charge-discharge efficiency is ultimately limited by the crystal growth of insol. Li2O2 on the porous cathode. Catalysts have been reported to improve the nucleation and morphol. of Li2O2, which helps achieve high energy densities. Lithium ions from electrolytes are found to interact with the surface oxygen sites and form surface lithium sites, facilitating further growth of Li2O2. A larger no. of initial growth points with uniform distribution makes Li2O2 well dispersed, forming small particles, which benefit both the ORR and oxygen evolution reactions (OER). This design concept for oxygen sites has been successfully validated by the real Li-O2 cell expts. with α-MnO2 nanowire cathodes.

Quant. differential electrochem. mass spectrometry and cyclic voltammetry were combined to probe possible mechanisms and the kinetic overpotentials, responsible for discharge and charge in a Li-O2 battery, using C as the cathode and an electrolyte based on dimethoxyethane as the solvent. Previous spectroscopy expts. (X-ray diffraction, μRaman, IR, XPS) have shown that Li2O2 is the principle product formed during Li-O2 discharge using this electrolyte/cathode combination. At all discharge potentials and charge potentials < 4.0 V, the obsd. electrochem. is ∼2e-/O2 consumed or produced, also implying that Li2O2 is the dominant thermodynamically stable species formed and consumed in the electrochem. No evidence exists at any potential for formation of stable LiO2 (1e-/O2) or Li2O (4e-/O2) during discharge. At charging potentials > 4.0 V, the electrochem. requires significantly more than 2e-/O2, and this taken as evidence for electrolyte decompn. It is found that sequential concerted (Li+ + e-) ion transfers to/from adsorbed O2* and LiO2* to produce/consume Li2O2 is the mechanism that is most compatible with these expts. The kinetic overpotentials are extremely low relative to aq. O2 redn. and evolution, and this implies that in principle a discharge-charge Li-O2 cycle is possible with high voltaic efficiency (∼85%) if electrolyte and cathode stability issues are resolved.

Metal-air batteries: from oxygen reduction electrochemistry to cathode catalysts
Cheng, Fangyi; Chen, Jun
Chemical Society Reviews
(
2012
),
41
(
6
),
2172-2192
CODEN:
CSRVBR
; ISSN:
0306-0012
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. Because of the remarkably high theor. energy output, metal-air batteries represent one class of promising power sources for applications in next-generation electronics, electrified transportation and energy storage of smart grids. The most prominent feature of a metal-air battery is the combination of a metal anode with high energy d. and an air electrode with open structure to draw cathode active materials (i.e., oxygen) from air. In this crit. review, we present the fundamentals and recent advances related to the fields of metal-air batteries, with a focus on the electrochem. and materials chem. of air electrodes. The battery electrochem. and catalytic mechanism of oxygen redn. reactions are discussed on the basis of aq. and org. electrolytes. Four groups of extensively studied catalysts for the cathode oxygen redn./evolution are selectively surveyed from materials chem. to electrode properties and battery application: Pt and Pt-based alloys (e.g., PtAu nanoparticles), carbonaceous materials (e.g., graphene nanosheets), transition-metal oxides (e.g., Mn-based spinels and perovskites), and inorg.-org. composites (e.g., metal macrocycle derivs.). The design and optimization of air-electrode structure are also outlined. Furthermore, remarks on the challenges and perspectives of research directions are proposed for further development of metal-air batteries (219 refs.).

Promoting Formation of Noncrystalline Li2O2 in the Li-O2 Battery with RuO2 Nanoparticles
Yilmaz, Eda; Yogi, Chihiro; Yamanaka, Keisuke; Ohta, Toshiaki; Byon, Hye Ryung

Low elec. efficiency for the lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) electrochem. reaction is one of the most significant challenges in current nonaq. Li-O2 batteries. Here we present RuO2 nanoparticles dispersed on multiwalled carbon nanotubes as a cathode, which dramatically increase the elec. efficiency up to 73%. We demonstrate that the RuO2 nanoparticles contribute to the formation of poorly cryst. Li2O2 that is coated over the carbon nanotubes with large contact area during oxygen redn. reaction. This unique Li2O2 structure can be smoothly decompd. at low potential upon oxygen evolution reaction by avoiding the energy loss assocd. with the decompn. of the more typical Li2O2 structure with a large size, small carbon nanotube contact area, and insulating crystals.

23
Oxygen electrocatalysts in metal-air batteries: from aqueous to nonaqueous electrolytes
Wang, Zhong-Li; Xu, Dan; Xu, Ji-Jing; Zhang, Xin-Bo
Chemical Society Reviews
(
2014
),
43
(
22
),
7746-7786
CODEN:
CSRVBR
; ISSN:
0306-0012
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
With the development of renewable energy and electrified transportation, electrochem. energy storage will be more important in the future than it has ever been in the past. Although lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are traditionally considered to be the most likeliest candidate thanks to their relatively long cycle life and high energy efficiency, their limited energy d. as well as cost are still causing a bottleneck for their long-term application. Alternatively, metal-air batteries have been proposed as a very promising large-scale electricity storage technol. with the replacement of the intercalation reaction mechanism by the catalytic redox reaction of a light wt. metal-oxygen couple. Generally, based on the electrolyte, these metal-air batteries can be divided into aq. and nonaq. systems, corresponding to two typical batteries of Zn-air and Li-air, resp. The prominent feature of both batteries are their extremely high theor. energy d., esp. for nonaq. Li-air batteries, which far exceeds the best that can be achieved with LIBs. In this review, we focus on the major obstacle of sluggish kinetics of the cathode in both batteries, and summarize the fundamentals and recent advances related to the oxygen catalyst materials. According to the electrolyte, the aq. and nonaq. electrocatalytic mechanisms of the oxygen redn. and evolution reactions are discussed. Subsequently, seven groups of oxygen catalysts, which have played catalytic roles in both systems, are selectively reviewed, including transition metal oxides (single-metal oxides and mixed-metal oxides), functional carbon materials (nanostructured carbons and doped carbons), metal oxide-nanocarbon hybrid materials, metal-nitrogen complexes (non-pyrolyzed and pyrolyzed), transition metal nitrides, conductive polymers, and precious metals (alloys). Nonaq. systems have the advantages of energy d. and rechargeability over aq. systems and have gradually become the research focus of metal-air batteries. However, there are considerable challenges beyond catalysts from aq. to nonaq. electrolytes, which are also discussed in this review. Finally, several future research directions are proposed based on the results achieved in this field, with emphasis on nonaq. Li-air batteries.

For the purpose of finding the catalytic active site for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in the crystal structure of Co3O4, a {100} faceted Co3O4 cube enclosed by only a Co2+ site and a {112} faceted Co3O4 plate also exposing a Co3+ site was adopted as a catalyst for lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries. Thus, we found that the Co3+ site plays the crucial role of detg. the adsorption properties of reactants, enabling high round-trip efficiency and cyclic stability, as well as the morphol. of discharge products such as Li2O2.

The authors report the intrinsic O redn. reaction (ORR) activity of polycryst. Pd, Pt, Ru, Au, and glassy C surfaces in 0.1 M LiClO4 1,2-dimethoxyethane via rotating disk electrode measurements. The nonaq. Li+-ORR activity of these surfaces primarily correlates to O adsorption energy, forming a volcano-type trend. The activity trend found on the polycryst. surfaces was in good agreement with the trend in the discharge voltage of Li-O2 cells catalyzed by nanoparticle catalysts. The authors' findings provide insights into Li+-ORR mechanisms in nonaq. media and design of efficient air electrodes for Li-air battery applications.

Platinum-gold nanoparticles: a highly active bifunctional electrocatalyst for rechargeable lithium-air batteries
Lu, Yi-Chun; Xu, Zhichuan; Gasteiger, Hubert A.; Chen, Shuo; Hamad-Schifferli, Kimberly; Shao-Horn, Yang

PtAu nanoparticles (NPs) were shown to strongly enhance the kinetics of the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in rechargeable Li-O2 cells. Li-O2 cells with PtAu/C were found to exhibit the highest round-trip efficiency reported to date. During ORR via xLi+ + O2 + xe- → LixO2, the discharge voltage with PtAu/C was considerably higher than that of pure carbon and comparable to that of Au/C. During OER via LixO2 → xLi+ + O2 + xe-, the charge voltages with PtAu/C fell in the range from 3.4 to 3.8 VLi, which is slightly lower than obtained with Pt. It is hypothesized that PtAu NPs exhibit bifunctional catalytic activity, having surface Au and Pt atoms primarily responsible for ORR and OER kinetics in Li-O2 cells, resp.

PdCu bimetallic nanoparticles (NPs) having mixed disordered face-centered cubic (fcc) and ordered body-centered cubic (B2-type) phases enhance the kinetics of oxygen redn./evolution reaction by significant redn. of overpotentials, which leads to the superb round-trip efficiency of ∼80%. Our first-principles calcns. demonstrate that the low overpotentials of the PdCu catalyst are strongly correlated with the weak LiO2 adsorption strength, caused by electron transfer from Cu to the top-layer Pd atoms on the surface.

Wang, Zhenyu; Chen, Xin; Cheng, Yonghong; Niu, Chunming
Journal of Physical Chemistry C
(

The Li2O2 adsorption and deposition on the low index surfaces of pristine and oxidized TiC has been investigated. The pristine TiC surface was not stable toward interaction with Li2O2 and that surface stability could be enhanced greatly by surface oxidn. as shown by surface energy redn. from 102 to 23 meV/Å2 for the TiC{100} surface and from 208 to 39 meV/Å2 for the TiC{111} surface after oxidn. Adsorption of two Li2O2 clusters on the 2 × 2 Ti-terminated TiC{111} surface (TiC{111}_Ti) resulted in spontaneous destruction of Li2O2 clusters and formation of a satd. periodic two at. layer coating in which each O atom was bonded to three Ti atoms to form an O layer equiv. to the layer formed by O2 surface oxidn., and Li atoms sat on the top. The at. arrangement of O and Li layers resembled that of Li1O2 layers normal to the [0001] direction in the Li2O2 crystal structure. Interface models constructed based on this lead showed that the growth of Li2O2 could be continued on oxidized TiC{111}_Ti through a surface conduction mechanism to form Li2O2 coating with lattice parameters almost identical to those of the std. Li2O2 unit cell. On the oxidized TiC{100} surface (TiC{100}_TiO), two Li2O2 clusters adsorbed on two adjacent Ti sites by Ti-O bonding with the O-O axis in Li2O2 perpendicular to the surface resulted in a Li and O atom configuration which is similar to O2Li3O4 layers in the Li2O2 crystal structure, indicating a potential path for Li2O2 nucleation on the TiC{100}_TiO surface. Interface models by following this path suggested that Li2O2 coating may be grown on the TiC{100}_TiO surface with a dihedral angle between 11.4° and 22.4°, and strains inside the Li2O2 could induce cond. These atomistic insights are in good agreement with the exptl. findings.

The efficient reversible formation of discharge products for Li-O2 batteries is still challenging. Meanwhile, the question of the nature of the discharge products and their decompn. mechanism are still remain. Implanting oxygen vacancies on the metal oxides can create neg.-charge surface to provide strong adsorption of active oxygen and at the same time, the exposed metal sites can serve as an efficient substrate for decompd. reaction of discharge products. In this work, we apply the graphene-like MoO3 ultrathin nanosheets as a matrix. By controlling the redn. time, the MoO3 nanosheets with different concn. of oxygen vacancy are obtained. Exptl. results reveal that the MoO3 nanosheets with the high-concn. oxygen vacancies can significantly decrease the overpotential and get enhanced electrochem. response, namely, a low overpotential of ∼0.5 V can be delivered with ultra-stable cycles (over 60 cycles). Moreover, the Li-O2 batteries demonstrate an interesting four-step discharge and charge process. XPS, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and electron energy-loss spectroscopy analyses are carried out for the four typical states of the cathode to reveal the reaction mechanism for the unique electrochem. behavior.

Lyu, Zhiyang; Yang, Lijun; Luan, Yanping; Wang, Xiao Renshaw; Wang, Liangjun; Hu, Zehua; Lu, Junpeng; Xiao, Shuning; Zhang, Feng; Wang, Xizhang; Huo, Fengwei; Huang, Wei; Hu, Zheng; Chen, Wei

Understanding and controlling the growth of the vital Li2O2 product, which is assocd. with intrinsic property of cathode surface, is essential to design effective cathode catalysts in Li-O2 batteries. Herein we establish the correlation between the Li2O2 growth model and the O2 adsorbability on cathode surface that dets. the pathway of the first electron transfer to O2. The weak O2 adsorbability drives the soln. growth model to form Li2O2 toroid, while the strong one drives the surface growth model to thin film. Based on this mechanism, we select the N-doped carbon nanocages as cathode to realize a simultaneous large discharge capacity and low charge overpotential by forming copious thin-film Li2O2, deriving from its high sp. surface area and enhanced O2 adsorbability due to N-doping. Our study demonstrates an effective strategy to design advanced cathode catalysts in Li-O2 batteries and potentially other metal-air batteries.

Platinum-Coated Hollow Graphene Nanocages as Cathode Used in Lithium-Oxygen Batteries
Wu, Feng; Xing, Yi; Zeng, Xiaoqiao; Yuan, Yifei; Zhang, Xiaoyi; Shahbazian-Yassar, Reza; Wen, Jianguo; Miller, Dean J.; Li, Li; Chen, Renjie; Lu, Jun; Amine, Khalil

One of the formidable challenges facing aprotic lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries is the high charge overpotential, which induces the formation of byproducts, loss in efficiency, and poor cycling performance. Herein, the synthesis of the ultrasmall Pt-coated hollow graphene nanocages as cathode in Li-O2 batteries is reported. The charge voltage plateau can reduce to 3.2 V at the c.d. of 100 mA g-1, even maintain below 3.5 V when the c.d. increased to 500 mA g-1. The unique hollow graphene nanocages matrix can not only provide numerous nanoscale tri-phase regions as active sites for efficient oxygen redn., but also offer sufficient amt. of mesoscale pores for rapid oxygen diffusion. Furthermore, with strong at.-level oxygen absorption into its subsurface, ultrasmall Pt catalytically serves as the nucleation site for Li2O2 growth. The Li2O2 is subsequently induced into a favorable form with small size and amorphous state, decompd. more easily during recharge. Meanwhile, the conductive hollow graphene substrate can enhance the catalytic activity of noble metal Pt catalysts due to the graphene-metal interfacial interaction. Benefiting from the above synergistic effects between the hollow graphene nanocages and the nanosized Pt catalysts, the ultrasmall Pt-decorated graphene nanocage cathode exhibits enhanced electrochem. performances.

Platinum nanoarchitectures consisting of a large no. of edges and corner atoms are highly favorable for enhancing the catalytic performance and efficient utilization of platinum. In a recent study, Pluronic F127 triblock copolymer can assist the formation of dendritic platinum nanoparticles. This concept is expanded to produce platinum nanodendrites with interconnected arms by using various types of nonionic org. mols. Nanodendrites with complex nanoarchitectures are produced simply by a sonicating treatment of an aq. soln. contg. a K2PtCl4 precursor and formic acid in the presence of nonionic org. mols. without the need for any template, seed-mediated growth, and additive. The resulting nanodendrites were active as nanoelectrocatalysts for electro-oxidn. by formic acid. The investigated nonionic org. mols. include nonionic surfactants such as Pluronic F127, Brij 700, Tetronic 1107, and polymers, e.g., poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) and 1-vinylpyrrolidone-vinyl acetate copolymer. The typical nanodendrites produced with Pluronic F127 possess platinum at. cryst. state with large domains and have a high surface area of 32 m2/g. The proposed approach is highly favorable for facilitating the prodn. of nanodendrites in a wide range of platinum precursor concns. Because of its high flexibility and simple implementation, the proposed approach can be considered as a general and powerful strategy for producing Pt nanodendrites with high surface area and open dendritic nanostructures for com. devices. Furthermore, the dual roles of formic acid in synthesis of nanodendrites, i.e., reducing agent and structure-directing agent, are tentatively proposed based.

The authors present an efficient scheme for calcg. the Kohn-Sham ground state of metallic systems using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set. In the first part the application of Pulay's DIIS method (direct inversion in the iterative subspace) to the iterative diagonalization of large matrixes will be discussed. This approach is stable, reliable, and minimizes the no. of order Natoms3 operations. In the second part, we will discuss an efficient mixing scheme also based on Pulay's scheme. A special "metric" and a special "preconditioning" optimized for a plane-wave basis set will be introduced. Scaling of the method will be discussed in detail for non-self-consistent and self-consistent calcns. It will be shown that the no. of iterations required to obtain a specific precision is almost independent of the system size. Altogether an order Natoms2 scaling is found for systems contg. up to 1000 electrons. If we take into account that the no. of k points can be decreased linearly with the system size, the overall scaling can approach Natoms. They have implemented these algorithms within a powerful package called VASP (Vienna ab initio simulation package). The program and the techniques have been used successfully for a large no. of different systems (liq. and amorphous semiconductors, liq. simple and transition metals, metallic and semiconducting surfaces, phonons in simple metals, transition metals, and semiconductors) and turned out to be very reliable.

Herein, we provide crit. information via first-principles calcns. to solve one of the major problems of Li-O2 batteries, namely, large overpotentials during the charge-discharge process. First, we found that PtCo exhibits remarkably low oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotentials of 0.19 and 0.20 V, resp. These are considerably lower than those of pure Pt (1.02 and 1.62 V, resp.) and of high-performance Pt3Co (1.02 and 1.13 V, resp.). The compn. optimization of bimetallic catalysts is therefore crit. in developing an optimal Li-O2 battery catalyst with an overpotential of nearly zero. Second, our calcns. demonstrate that replacing the late transition metal Co in Pt3Co with the early transition metal Ti significantly decreases overpotentials, yielding ORR and OER overpotentials of 0.34 and 0.82 V, resp. These results are opposite to those obtained for fuel cells. Notably, our results suggest that a bimetallic catalyst with poor catalytic activity in fuel cells might show excellent activity in Li-O2 cells. In particular, combinations of active Pt with early transition metals should be studied for development of bimetallic catalysts with high round-trip efficiency in Li-O2 batteries. Finally, we suggest that the adsorption energies of Li and LiO2 are crit. descriptors of catalytic activity and that they should be used to screen new candidate materials. This is because low ORR and OER overpotentials are closely related to strong Li and weak LiO2 adsorptions, resp., on the catalytic surface.

The key factor to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries is to find effective cathode catalysts to promote the oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions. Herein, we report the synthesis of an effective cathode catalyst of ruthenium nanocrystals supported on carbon black substrate by a surfactant assisting method. The as-prepared ruthenium nanocrystals exhibited an excellent catalytic activity as cathodes in Li-O2 batteries with a high reversible capacity of about 9,800 mAh g-1, a low charge-discharge over-potential (about 0.37 V), and an outstanding cycle performance up to 150 cycles (with a curtaining capacity of 1,000 mAh g-1). The electrochemical testing shows that ruthenium nanocrystals can significantly reduce the charge potential comparing to carbon black catalysts, which demonstrated that ruthenium based nanomaterials could be effective cathode catalysts for high performance lithium- O2 batteries.

The electrocatalytic performance of the prepd. samples was evaluated by tracking the decompn. of Li2O2 during the charging process in a Li-O2 cell using in situ XRD and operando SR-PXD, which gave direct and time resolved information during the whole process. Li/O2 battery has the highest theor. energy d. among any battery systems reported to date. However, its poor cycle life and unacceptable energy efficiency from a high charging overpotential have been major limitations. Recently, much higher energy efficiency with low overpotential was reported for a new metal/oxygen system, Na/O2 battery. This finding was unexpected since the general battery mechanism of the Na/O2 system was assumed to be analogous to that of the Li/O2 cell. Furthermore, it implies that fundamentally different kinetics are at work in the two systems. Here, we investigated the reaction mechanisms in the Na/O2 cell using first-principles PAW DFT-PBE calcns. In comparative study with the Li/O2 cell, we constructed the phase stability maps of the reaction products of Na/O2 and Li/O2 batteries based on the oxygen partial pressure, which explained why certain phases should be the main discharge products under different operating conditions. From surface calcns. of NaO2, Na2O2, and Li2O2 during the oxygen evolution reaction, we also found that the min. energy barrier for the NaO2 decompn. was substantially lower than that of Li2O2 decompn. on major surfaces providing a hint for low charging overpotential of Na/O2 battery.

Influence of Nonaqueous Solvents on the Electrochemistry of Oxygen in the Rechargeable Lithium-Air Battery
Laoire, Cormac O.; Mukerjee, Sanjeev; Abraham, K. M.; Plichta, Edward J.; Hendrickson, Mary A.
Journal of Physical Chemistry C
(
2010
),

(

),
9178-9186

1932-7447

American Chemical Society

The influence of solvents on the O redn. reaction (ORR) in nonaq. electrolytes was studied for the mechanism of O electrode processes in a rechargeable Li-air battery. Using either Bu4NPF6 (TBAPF6) or LiPF6 electrolyte solns. in 4 different solvents, DMSO, MeCN, dimethoxyethane (DME), and tetraethylene glycol di-Me ether (TEGDME), possessing a range of donor nos. (DN), the solvent and the supporting electrolyte cations in the soln. act in concert to influence the nature of redn. products and their rechargeability. In solns. contg. TBA+, O2 redn. is a reversible 1-electron process involving the O2/O2- couple. However, in Li+-contg. electrolytes relevant to the Li-air battery, O2 redn. proceeds in a stepwise fashion to form O2-, O22-, and O2- as products. These reactions in the presence of Li+ are irreversible or quasi-reversible electrochem. processes, and the solvents have significant influence on the kinetics, and reversibility or lack thereof, of the different redn. products. The stabilization of the 1-electron redn. product, superoxide (O2-) in TBA+ solns. in all of the solvents examd. can be explained using Pearson's hard/soft acid base (HSAB) theory involving the formation of the TBA+---O2- complex. The HSAB theory coupled with the relative stabilities of the Li+-(solvent)n complexes existing in the different solvents also provide an explanation for the different O2 redn. products formed in Li+-conducting electrolyte solns. Reversible redn. of O2 to long-lived superoxide in a Li+-conducting electrolyte in DMSO was shown for the 1st time here. The results aid the selection of org. electrolyte solns. for use in rechargeable Li-air batteries.

Intense interest in the Li-O2 battery system over the past 5 years has led to a much better understanding of the various chem. processes involved in the functioning of this battery system. However, detailed decompn. of the nanostructured Li2O2 product, held at least partially responsible for the limited reversibility and poor rate performance, is hard to measure operando under realistic electrochem. conditions. Here, we report operando nanobeam X-ray diffraction expts. that enable monitoring of the decompn. of individual Li2O2 grains in a working Li-O2 battery. Platelet-shaped crystallites with aspect ratios between 2.2 and 5.5 decomp. preferentially via the more reactive (001) facets. The slow and concurrent decompn. of individual Li2O2 crystallites indicates that the Li2O2 decompn. rate limits the charge time of these Li-O2 batteries, highlighting the importance of using redox mediators in soln. to charge Li-O2 batteries.

Ryu, Won-Hee; Yoon, Taek-Han; Song, Sung Ho; Jeon, Seokwoo; Park, Yong-Joon; Kim, Il-Doo
